description: From Middle French ubiquit√©, from Latin ubique.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The state or quality of being, or appearing to be, everywhere at once; actual or perceived omnipresence.
examples: It would be hard to exaggerate the ubiquity of the diminutive (-ito, -ita) in Latin American Spanish, which originates from the extreme reverence and indulgence accorded to the young.

entries.meaning: (countable, sciences) Anything that is ubiquitous within a specified area.
